t: In*p the past God spoke to our ancestors through the prophets at many times and in various ways,
but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, and through whom also he made the universe.

The Son is the radiance of God’s glory and the exact representation of his being, sustaining all things by his powerful word. After he had provided purification for sins, he sat down at the right hand of the Majesty in heaven.
So he became as much superior to the angels as the name he has inherited is superior to theirs.
For*p to which of the angels did God ever say, “You*pn are my Son; today*ld I have become your Father”? Or*p again, “I*pn will be his Father, and*ld he will be my Son”?
And*p again, when God brings his firstborn into the world, he says, “Let*pn all God’s angels worship him.”
In*p speaking of the angels he says, “He*pn makes his angels spirits, and*ld his servants flames of fire.”
But*p about the Son he says, “Your*pn throne, O God, will last for ever and ever; a*ld scepter of justice will be the scepter of your kingdom.
You*ln have loved righteousness and hated wickedness; therefore*ld God, your God, has set you above your companions by*ld anointing you with the oil of joy.”
He*p also says, “In*pn the beginning, Lord, you laid the foundations of the earth, and*ld the heavens are the work of your hands.
They*ln will perish, but you remain; they*ld will all wear out like a garment.
You*ln will roll them up like a robe; like*ld a garment they will be changed. But*ln you remain the same, and*ld your years will never end.”
To*p which of the angels did God ever say, “Sit*pn at my right hand until*ld I make your enemies a*ld footstool for your feet”?
Are*p not all angels ministering spirits sent to serve those who will inherit salvation?
